Sweet Teviot, by adventurous Leyden sung,</br>And famed by mighty Scott in deathless lays,</br>I may not hope, with far less gifted tongue,</br>Aught higher to advance thy classic praise;</br>Yet, as a son his pious tribute pays</br>To the loved mother he has left behind,</br>I fain some grateful monument would raise,</br>Which in far foreign lands may call to mind</br>The scenes that Scottish hearts to their dear country bind.

And, though the last and lowliest of the train</br>By haunted Teviot smit with love of song,</br>(Sweet witchery that charms full many a pain!)</br>I join with venturous voice the minstrel throng:</br>For NATURE is the nurse to whom belong</br>Alike the thrush that cheers the broomy dale,</br>And the proud swan that, on bold pinions strong,</br>Through the far tracts of ether dares to sail,</br>And pours 'mid scenes sublime his soul-subduing wail.

No perilous theme I meditate:  to me</br>To soar 'mid clouds and storms hath not been given;</br>Or through the gates of Dread and Mystery</br>To gaze — like those dark spirits who have striven</br>To rend the veil that severs Earth from Heaven:</br>For I have loved with simple hearts to dwell,</br>That ne'er to Doubt's forbidden springs were driven</br>But lived sequestered in life's lowly dell,</br>And drank the untroubled stream from Inspiration's well.

Such were thy virtuous sons, fair Teviotdale,</br>While old simplicity was yet in prime;</br>But now among thy glens the faithful fail,</br>Forgetful of our sires in olden time:</br>That grey-haired race is gone — of look sublime,</br>Calm in demeanour, courteous, and sincere;</br>Yet stern, when duty called them, as their clime</br>When it flings off the autumnal foliage sere,</br>And shakes the shuddering woods with solemn voice severe.

And such were they whose tale I now rehearse—</br>But not to fashion's minions, who in vain</br>Would ask amusement from the artless verse</br>Of one who sings to sooth long hours of pain:</br>A nameless exile o'er the southern main,</br>I pour 'mid savage wilds my pensive song;</br>And if some gentle spirits love the strain,</br>Enough for me, though midst the louder throng</br>Few may be found to prize, or listen to it long.

A rustic home in Lynden's pastoral dell</br>With modest pride a verdant hillock crowned;</br>Where the bold stream, like dragon from the fell,</br>Came glittering forth, and, gently gliding round</br>The broom-clad skirts of that fair spot of ground,</br>Danced down the vale, in wanton mazes bending;</br>Till finding, where it reached the meadow's bound,</br>Romantic Teviot on his bright course wending,</br>It joined the sounding streams — with his blue waters blending.

Behind, a lofty wood along the steep</br>Fenced from the chill north-east this quiet glen;</br>And green hills, gaily sprinkled o'er with sheep,</br>Spread to the south; while, by the bughting-pen,</br>Rose the blithe sound of flocks and hounds and men,</br>At summer dawn and gloaming; of the voice</br>Of children nutting in the hazelly den,</br>Sweet mingling with the wind's and water's noise,</br>Attuned the softened heart with Nature to rejoice.

Upon the upland height a mouldering Tower,</br>By time and outrage marked with many a scar,</br>Told of past days of feudal pomp and power</br>When its proud chieftains ruled the dales afar.</br>But that was long gone by:  and waste and war,</br>And civil strife more ruthless still than they,</br>Had quenched the lustre of Glen-Lynden's star—</br>Which glimmered now, with dim declining ray,</br>O'er this secluded spot, — sole remnant of their sway.

A grave mild husbandman was Lynden's lord,</br>Who, smiling o'er these wrecks of grandeur gone,</br>Had for the plough-share changed the warrior's sword</br>Which, like his sires, he erst had girded on.</br>And on his toils relenting Fortune shone,</br>And blessed his fruitful fields and fleecy store;</br>And she he loved in youth, and loved alone,</br>Was his:  ah, what could wealth have added more,</br>Save pride and peevish cares which haunt the rich man's door?

Vain wealth or rank could ne'er have won such love</br>As that devoted bosom's, — lofty, warm,—</br>Which, while it blooms below, puts forth above</br>Celestial shoots secure from earthly harm.</br>And now his pleasant home and pastoral farm</br>Are all the world to him:  he feels no sting</br>Of restless passions; but, with grateful arm,</br>Clasps the twin cherubs around his neck that cling,</br>Breathing their innocent thoughts like violets in Spring.

Another prattler, too, lisps on his knee,</br>The orphan daughter of a hapless pair,</br>Who, voyaging upon the Indian sea,</br>Met the fierce typhon-blast — and perished there:</br>But she was left the rustic home to share</br>Of those who her young mother's friends had been;</br>And old affection thus enhanced the care</br>With which those faithful guardians loved to screen</br>This sweet forsaken flower, in their wild arbours green.

With their twin children dark-eyed Helen grew—</br>(Arthur and Anna were the kindred twain)—</br>And she, the engrafted germ, appeared to view</br>So like  a younger sister, that 'twere pain</br>To think that group should ever part again:</br>They grew, like three fair roses on one stalk,</br>In budding beauty yet without a stain:</br>So the fond parents oft in kindly talk</br>Would say — nor dreamt how fate their blooming hopes might balk.

But dark calamity comes aye too soon—</br>And why anticipate its evil day?</br>Ah, rather let us now in lovely June</br>O'er look these happy children at their play:</br>Lo, where they gambol through the garden gay,</br>Or round the hoary hawthorn dance and sing,</br>Or, 'neath yon moss-grown cliff, grotesque and grey,</br>Sit plaiting flowery wreathes in social ring,</br>And telling wondrous tales of the green Elfin King.

And Elfin lore and ancient Border song</br>The mother, smiling o'er the eager train,</br>Would often chaunt in winter evenings long—</br>And oft they pressed the pleasing task again:</br>But still she warned them that such tales were vain,</br>And but the dotage of a darker time;</br>And urged them better knowledge to attain</br>While yet their pliant minds were in their prime,</br>And open for the seed of scripture truth sublime.

Then would she tell — and in far other tone—</br>Of evil times gone by and evil men—</br>"When they who worshipped God must meet alone</br>At midnight, in the cleugh or quaking fen,</br>In peril and alarm, — for round them then</br>Were ranging those who hunted for their blood:</br>Ay!  long shall we remember! — In this glen,</br>From yon grim cavern where the screech-owls brood</br>Our ancestor was dragged, like outlaw from the wood!

"He died a victim; and his ancient lands,</br>Held by Glen-Lynden's lords since Bruce's day,</br>Have passed for ever to the spoiler's hands!"—</br>—"Hush thee!"  the father then would gently say;</br>"'Twas Heaven's good pleasure we that debt should pay—</br>Perchance for guilt of those fierce feudal lords,</br>Who, void of pity, when they shared the prey</br>Full often in the balance flung their swords,</br>And wasted orphans' lands with their marauding hordes."

Such was their talk around the evening hearth:</br>And mildly thus, as the young playmates grew,</br>They taught them to join trembling with their mirth;</br>For life is but a pilgrim's passage through</br>A waste, where springs of joy are faint and few:</br>Yet, lest this thought their hearts too much o'ercast,</br>They oft would turn to lightsome themes anew;</br>For youth's hilarity we must not blast,</br>But lead it kindly on to wisdom's paths at last.

Fain would I linger 'mong those fairy bowers,</br>Aloof from manhood's feverish hopes and fears,</br>Where Innocence among the vernal flowers</br>Leads young Delight, aye laughing through his tears:</br>But lo!  the cruel spectre Time appears,</br>Half hid amidst the foliage bright with bloom,</br>Weaving his ceaseless web of hours and years,</br>Still onward dyed with deeper hues of gloom—</br>And Death behind stands darkly — pointing to the tomb!

Ay!  Time's harsh hand for youth nor age will stay—</br>And I must hasten with my lagging strain.</br>Years steal on years:  the locks are wearing grey</br>On either parent's brow:  the youthful train</br>Have long outgrown their childish pastimes vain:</br>On Arthur's manly features we may trace</br>High thought and feeling, checked by anxious pain;</br>And, in each timid maiden's milder face,</br>Some shade of pensive care with woman's opening grace.

So young — so innocent — can grief's dark cloud</br>Thus early o'er their hearts its shadow fling?</br>Affliction's angel, though he crush the proud,</br>Might pass the humble with relenting wing!</br>Yet death has not been here; nor hath the sting</br>Of baleful passion touched one gentle breast:</br>Whence then can venomed care and sorrow spring,</br>In this calm seat of love and pious rest?</br>And the dear parent twain — why look they so distressed?

Ah!  evil days have fallen upon the land:</br>A storm that brooded long has burst at last;</br>And friends, like forest trees that closely stand</br>With roots and branches interwoven fast,</br>May aid awhile each other in the blast;</br>But as when giant pines at length give way</br>The groves below must share the ruin vast,</br>So men who seemed aloof from Fortune's sway</br>Fall crushed beneath the shock of loftier than they.

Even so it fared.  And dark round Lynden grew</br>Misfortune's troubles; and foreboding fears,</br>That rose like distant shadows, nearer drew,</br>O'ercasting the calm evening of his years:</br>Yet still amidst the gloom fair hope appears,</br>A rainbow in the cloud.  And, for a space,</br>Till the horizon closes round, or clears,</br>Returns our tale the enchanted paths to trace</br>Where youth's fond visions rise with fair but fleeting grace.

Far up the dale, where Lynden's ruined towers</br>O'erlooked the valley from the old oak wood,</br>A lake, blue-gleaming from deep forest bowers,</br>Spread its fair mirror to the landscape rude:</br>Oft by the margin of that quiet flood,</br>And through the groves and hoary ruins round,</br>Young Arthur loved to roam in lonely mood;</br>Or, here amid tradition's haunted ground,</br>Long silent hours to lie in mystic musings drowned.

Bold feats of war, fierce feuds of elder times,</br>And wilder Elfin legends, — half forgot,</br>And half preserved in uncouth ballad rhymes,—</br>Had peopled with romantic tales the spot:</br>And, here, save bleat of sheep, or simple note</br>Of shepherd's pipe far on the upland lone,</br>Or linnet in the bush and lark afloat</br>Blithe carolling, or stockdove's plaintive moan,</br>No sound of living thing through the long day was known.

No sound — save, aye, one small brook's tinkling dash</br>Down the grey mossy cliffs; and, midst the lake,</br>The quick trout springing oft with gamesome plash;</br>And wild ducks rustling in the sedgy brake;</br>And sighing winds that scarce the willows shake;</br>And hum of bees among the blossomed thyme;</br>And pittering song of grasshoppers that make</br>Throughout the glowing meads their mirthful chime:</br>All rich and soothing sounds of summer's fragrant prime.

Here Arthur loved to roam — a dreaming boy—</br>Erewhile romantic reveries to frame,</br>Or read adventurous tales with thrilling joy,</br>Till his young breast throbbed high with thirst of fame:</br>But with fair manhood's dawn a softer flame</br>'Gan mingle with his martial musings high;</br>And trembling wishes, — which he feared to name,</br>Yet oft betrayed in many a half-drawn sigh,—</br>Told that the hidden shaft deep in his heart did lie.

And there were eyes that from long silken lashes</br>With stolen glance could spy his secret pain,—</br>Sweet hazel eyes, whose dewy light out-flashed</br>Like joyous day-spring after summer rain:</br>And she, the enchantress, loved the youth again</br>With maiden's first affection, fond and true.</br>—Ah!  youthful love is like the tranquil main</br>Heaving 'neath smiling skies its bosom blue—</br>Beautiful as a spirit — calm but fearful too!

And forth they wander, that fair girl and boy,</br>To roam in gladness through the summer bowers;</br>Of love they talk not, but love's tender joy</br>Breathes from their hearts like fragrance from the flowers:</br>Elysium opens round them; and the hours</br>Glide on unheeded, till grey Twilight's shade</br>Wraps in its wizard shroud the ivyed towers,</br>And fills with mystic shapes the forest glade—</br>And wakes "thick-coming fancies" in strange guise arrayed.

And oft they linger those lone haunts among,</br>Though darker fall the shadows of the wood,</br>And the witch-owl invokes with fitful song</br>The phantom train of Superstition's brood.</br>A gentle Star lights up their solitude,</br>And lends fair hues to all created things;</br>And dreams alone of beings pure and good</br>Hover around their hearts with angel wings—</br>Hearts, like sweet fountains sealed, where silent rapture springs.

I may not here their growing passion paint,</br>Or their day-dreams of cloudless bliss disclose:</br>I may not tell how hope deferred grew faint,</br>When griefs and troubles in far vista rose:</br>As the woods tremble ere the tempest blows,</br>How quaked their hearts (misled by treacherous fears)</br>When that fell nightmare of the soul's repose,</br>Green Jealousy his snaky crest uprears,</br>Whose breath of mildew blights the cherished faith of years.
———*———*———*———*———*———

'Tis Autumn's pensive noon:  no zephyr's breath</br>The withered foliage in the woods is shaking;</br>Their feeble song the mournful birds bequeath</br>To the sere coverts they are fast forsaking:</br>And now their last farewell that pair are taking;</br>For Arthur, bound to Indian climes, must leave</br>These early haunts.  Each silent heart is breaking—</br>Yet both attempt to hide how much they grieve—</br>And each, deceived in turn, the other doth deceive.

How can they part? — The lake, the woods, the hills,</br>Speak to their pensive hearts of early days;</br>Remembrance woos them from the haunted rills,</br>And hallows every spot their eye surveys;</br>Some sweet memorial of their infant plays,</br>Some tender token of their bashful loves,</br>Each rock, and tree, and sheltered nook displays:</br>How can they part? — Nature the crime reproves,</br>And their commingling souls to milder purpose moves!

For what were life — ah what were weary life,</br>Without each other, in this world of care?</br>A voyage through wild seas of storm and strife,</br>Without an aim for which to struggle there.</br>But, blessed in wedded bands, how sweet to share</br>The gladness or the grief that life may bring!</br>Then join, relenting Love!  this gentle pair;</br>Let worldly hearts to gold and grandeur cling;</br>Around the lowly cot thy turtles sweetest sing.

Yes!  they shall part no more!  Those downcast eyes,</br>And blushes mantling o'er the changeful cheek—</br>The plighted kiss — the tears — the trembling sighs—</br>The head upon his arms reclining meek—</br>Tell far more tenderly than words can speak,</br>How that devoted heart is all his own!</br>Oh, Love is eloquent — but language weak</br>To paint the feelings to pure bosoms known,</br>When Transport's heavenly wings are sweetly round them thrown!

And now the lake, the hills, the yellow woods,</br>Are bathed in beauty by the parting ray:</br>Through earth and air a hallowed rapture broods,</br>And starting tears confess  its mystic sway:</br>As home they wend, amidst the year's decay,</br>Some magic spell the hues of Eden throws</br>O'er every scene that, on their outward way,</br>Told but of pleasures past and coming woes:</br>Such the enchanted radiance heart-felt bliss bestows.

Oh Nature!  by impassioned hearts alone</br>Thy genuine charms are felt.  The vulgar mind</br>Sees but the shadow of a Power unknown:</br>Thy loftier beauties beam not to the blind</br>And sensual throng, to grovelling hopes resigned:</br>But they whom high and holy thoughts inspire</br>Adore thee, in celestial glory shrined,</br>In that diviner fane where Love's pure fire</br>Burns bright, and Genius tunes his loud immortal lyre!
———*———*———*———*———*———

Change we once more the strain.  The sire has told</br>The heart-struck group of dark disaster nigh:</br>Their old paternal home must now be sold,</br>And that last relic of their ancestry</br>Resigned to strangers.  Long and strenuously</br>He strove to stem the flood's o'erwhelming mass;</br>But still some fresh unseen calamity</br>Burst like a foaming billow — till, alas!</br>No hope remains that this their sorest grief may pass.

"Yet be not thus dismayed.  Our altered lot</br>He that ordains will brace us to endure.</br>This changeful world affords no sheltered spot</br>Where man may count his frail possessions sure.</br>Our better birthright, noble, precious, pure,</br>May well console for earthly treasures marred,</br>Treasures, alas!  how vain and insecure,</br>Where none from rust and robbery can guard:</br>The wise man looks to heaven alone for his reward."

The Christian father thus.  But whither now</br>Shall the bewildered band their course direct?</br>What home shall shield that matron's honoured brow,</br>And those dear pensive maids from wrong protect?</br>Or cheer them 'mid the world's unkind neglect?</br>That world to the unfortunate so cold,</br>While lavish of its smiles and fair respect</br>Unto the proud, the prosperous, the bold;</br>Still shunning want and woe; still courting pomp and gold.

Shall they adopt the poor retainer's trade,</br>And sue for pity from the great and proud?</br>No!  never shall ungenerous souls upbraid</br>Their conduct in adversity — which bowed</br>But not debased them.  Or, amidst the crowd,</br>In noisome towns shall they themselves immure,</br>Their wants, their woes, their weary ways to shroud</br>In some mean melancholy nook obscure?</br>No!  worthier tasks await, and brighter scenes allure,

A land of climate fair, and fertile soil,</br>Teeming with milk and wine and waving corn,</br>Invites from far the venturous Briton's toil:</br>And thousands, long by fruitless cares foreworn,</br>Are now across the wide Atlantic borne,</br>To seek new homes on Afric's southern strand:</br>Better to launch with them than sink forlorn</br>To vile dependence in our native land;</br>Better to fall in God's than man's unfeeling hand!

With hearts resigned they tranquilly prepare</br>To share the fortunes of that exile train.</br>And soon, with many a follower, forth they fare—</br>High hope and courage in their hearts again:</br>And now, afloat upon the dark-blue main,</br>They gaze upon the fast-receding shore</br>With tearful eyes — while thus the ballad strain,</br>Half-heard amidst the ocean's weltering roar,</br>Bids farewell to the scenes they ne'er shall visit more:—
"Our native Land, our native Vale,</br>A long and last adieu!</br>Farewell to bonny Lynden-dale,</br>And Cheviot-mountains blue!
"Farewell, ye hills of glorious deeds,</br>And streams renowned in song;</br>Farewell, ye blithesome braes and meads</br>Our hearts have loved so long.
"Farewell, ye broomy elfin knowes,</br>Where thyme and harebells grow;</br>Farewell, ye hoary haunted howes,</br>O'er hung with birk and sloe.
"The battle-mound, the Border-tower,</br>That Scotia's annals tell;</br>The martyr's grave, the lover's bower—</br>To each — to all — farewell!
"Home of our hearts!  our fathers' home!</br>Land of the brave and free</br>The keel is flashing  through the foam</br>That bears us far from thee.
"We seek a wild and distant shore</br>Beyond the Atlantic main;</br>We leave thee to return no more,</br>Nor view thy cliffs again.
"But may dishonour blight our fame,</br>And quench our household fires</br>When we, or ours, forget thy name,</br>Green Island of our Sires!
"Our native Land — our native Vale—</br>A long, a last adieu!</br>Farewell to bonny Lynden-dale,</br>And Scotland's mountains blue!"

Sweet Teviot, fare thee well.  Less gentle themes</br>Abruptly call me from thy pastoral vale,</br>To where far Amakosa's woods and streams</br>Spread faint before me in the moonlight pale,</br>And from deep wildering dales I hear the wail</br>Of broken hearts — the mother and the child:</br>How can I dally with a lover's tale,</br>In Fiction's bowers — while peals in anguish wild</br>To heaven the bitter cry of Afric's race reviled?

From Keissi's meads, from Chumi's hoary woods,</br>Bleak Tarka's dens, and Stormberg's rugged fells,</br>To where Gariep pours down his sounding floods</br>Through regions where the hunted Bushman dwells,</br>That bitter cry wide o'er the desert swells,</br>And, like a spirit's voice, demands the song</br>That of these savage haunts the story tells—</br>A tale of foul oppression, fraud, and wrong,</br>By Afric's sons endured from Christian Europe long.

Adieu, soft lays, to love and fancy dear:</br>Let darker themes a sterner verse inspire,</br>While I attune to strains that tyrants fear</br>The louder murmurs of the British lyre,—</br>And from a loftier altar ask the fire</br>To point the indignant line with heavenly light,</br>(Though soon again in darkness to expire!)</br>That I may blast Oppression's cruel might,</br>By flashing TRUTH'S full blaze on deeds deep hid in night!</br>
